headline: Potential Rams draft targets: UCLA’s Sean Rhyan provides OL versatility
author: Kevin Modesti
sentences: Without their picks in the first round (which they gave up to the Lions in the January 2021 trade for quarterback Matthew Stafford) or second round (sent along with their third-rounder to the Broncos in the November 2021 trade for Miller), the Rams aren’t scheduled to make a selection until late in the third round (with the compensatory pick for losing executive Brad Holmes to the Lions last year), then have seven more picks in rounds 3-7.

The offensive line is the most likely to need reinforcements, with left tackle Andrew Whitworth considering retirement at age 40, and his backup Joe Noteboom eligible for unrestricted free agency, as are starting right guard Austin Corbett and center Brian Allen.

Here’s a look at players who could help the Rams and drew attention at the combine, with scouting reports from SCNG’s Gilbert Manzano, who spent the week in Indianapolis:
Sean Rhyan, OL, UCLA
The former Bruins standout impressed at the combine.

Cole Strange, OL, Chattanooga
Strange gained attention in the Senior Bowl as a center and earned more recognition at the combine as a quality interior offensive lineman who could go in the middle rounds thanks to his 5.03 40-yard dash.

Linebacker is another, with starting outside backer Von Miller’s and backup Ogbonnia Okoronkwo’s contracts up, and inside backers Troy Reeder (restricted free agency) and Travin Howard (exclusive-rights free agency) uncertain to stay.

Snead knows this feeds the impression the Rams view draft picks mostly as trade capital, an image he played along with at the championship parade by wearing a T-shirt with a profane joke about the picks.
Which positions will be most important to target in the April 28-30 draft will depend on which free agents they lose and gain after the start of the league year March 16.

Cam Jurgens, C, Nebraska
Jurgens helped his draft stock by providing teams with homemade beef jerky and delivering an impressive time of 4.92 seconds in the 40-yard dash.
General manager Les Snead and coach Sean McVay didn’t go to Indianapolis, using the time to catch up on off-season planning after the Rams’ Super Bowl victory.
He primarily played left tackle in college, but the San Juan Hills High grad has the versatility to contribute as an offensive guard or right tackle.
The 6-foot-5, 307-pound Strange, who played tackle and guard in college, has the lateral quickness to contribute in zone-blocking schemes.
The scouts who are in Indy have been looking for mid- to late-round draft prospects, since the Rams have no first- or second-round picks.
OTHERS TO TARGET: Josh Jobe, CB, Alabama; Coby Bryant, CB, Cincinnati; Terrel Bernard, LB, Baylor; Aaron Hansford, LB, Texas A&M
Paul played offensive tackle in college, but his 6-foot-4, 323-pound frame could lead to a position change at offensive guard.
NFL Network draft analyst Daniel Jeremiah raved about Jurgens during the combine broadcast and shared the beef jerky store.
“I’m comfortable at left tackle, but I can and I want to be able to help the team in the most ways,” Rhyan said.
Paul was known more for his leadership qualities and toughness on the field before participating in the combine.
Cornerback is another potential target area, with Darious Williams eligible for unrestricted free agency.
He’s now viewed as a third-round prospect after how well he did in the drills and 40-yard dash.
At 6-foot-3 and 303 pounds, Jurgens has the athleticism to hang with NFL defensive linemen.

Chris Paul, OL, Tulsa
His name definitely stood out, but so did his football movements.
The Rams took a different approach than most teams to this week’s NFL Scouting Combine.
“The draft is very, very important to us,” Snead said Wednesday.
He’s capable of providing depth and versatility for the Rams.
He’s polished in many areas and excels as a run blocker.
But he takes pains to set the record straight.
Teams are fans of his tenacious play.
